docs.snippet: WEEK ENDED JULY 26,1941 Activity in the foreign exchange market during the past week was practically at a standstill. Only a small number of transactions were reported and quotations moved within a narrow range. Rates for Japanese and Chinese...
docs.lead_paragraph: WEEK ENDED JULY 26,1941 Activity in the foreign exchange market during the past week was practically at a standstill. Only a small number of transactions were reported and quotations moved within a narrow range. Rates for Japanese and Chinese currencies were not available on Saturday due to President Roosevelt's proclamation of July 25, to "freeze" the assets of these countries.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Sumner Welles, acting Secretary of State, said today that recent developments had demonstrated that "the totalitarian powers are striving to disturb he peace of this hemisphere and to extend their disruptive control over the affairs of American republics."

docs.snippet: CHAIRMAN: Senator Tom Connally of Texas, whose first act as a member of Congress was to vote for the declaration of war against Germany in 1917, last week became chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. A stanch supporter of the Roosevelt...
docs.lead_paragraph: CHAIRMAN: Senator Tom Connally of Texas, whose first act as a member of Congress was to vote for the declaration of war against Germany in 1917, last week became chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. A stanch supporter of the Roosevelt Administration's foreign policy, Mr. Connally declared that no nation should be allowed to become "too big for its britches."

docs.snippet: A phenomenal improvement in the economic position of South America such as few would have forecast a year ago is apparent from recent foreign trade statistics. The trade of these countries with the United States in the second year of the war is...
docs.lead_paragraph: A phenomenal improvement in the economic position of South America such as few would have forecast a year ago is apparent from recent foreign trade statistics. The trade of these countries with the United States in the second year of the war is showing an abrupt reversal of the trend for the first year and now we are buying more from our "good neighbors" to the South than they are buying from us.

headline.main: TRADE NOW FAVORS SOUTH AMERICA; Shift in Balance Is Of Great Benefit to Our Neighbors
